instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in water damages near the wifi module, had a short on <CAPACITOR>C3700</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_WLS</SIGNAL> and some traces near <CAPACITOR>C3820</CAPACITOR> were gone, all that got repaired and cleaned up.

ppbus is 13v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulses from 5v to 3v to 2v very fast 
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> 13v
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> 3.2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message: This could be many things. Given it's history, check all rails for shorts. If you have a short down stream, this will happen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> goes to many chips.
I will start checking <CHIP>U8205</CHIP>/80, which both work on S5 state.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> should appear before any <SIGNAL>XVS4_EN</SIGNAL> signal is enabled.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message: Thank you both, I learned a lot on this one, there is a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL>, I injected 1v to it and the CPU heats up, nothing else, just to check I also removed <CHIP>U8205</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> in false hopes it would not be the CPU, but same thing, CPU heats up, any hope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message: If CPU heats up with 1V on 3V3 rail, there is no doubt...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message:
Ok so this board is done?

Do other techs replace CPUs?

Or replacing the CPU is not advisable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
threads.message: I think is better to find another board whit warranty.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails 20v at 0amps
